title: 108_hr3593
content: The "Campus Care and Counseling Act" is the short title of this legislation. It includes findings related to campus care and counseling services. The Congress finds that there is a significant increase in college students seeking counseling for psychological problems, with high rates of hopelessness, depression, and suicidal thoughts. Research shows a rise in depression among college freshmen, which can lead to academic failure and other negative outcomes. According to studies, college students are experiencing more stress, anxiety, and depression than a decade ago. A UCLA study found that over 30% of college freshmen feel overwhelmed at the beginning of college and may benefit from psychological services. The 2001 National Household Survey on Drug Abuse shows high rates of binge and heavy drinking among young adults. The highest prevalence of binge and heavy drinking is found in young adults aged 18 to 25, especially on college campuses. A Harvard School of Public Health study shows that 44.4% of college students are binge drinkers. 1400 college students die each year from alcohol-related injuries, and those who drink are more likely to engage in assault, sexual abuse, and vandalism. 25% of college students attribute academic problems to excessive drinking. According to the 2001 National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, 20 percent of full-time undergraduate college students use illicit drugs. The survey also found that 18.4 percent of adults aged 18 to 24 are dependent on or abusing illicit drugs or alcohol. Additionally, among adults with serious mental illness in 2001, 20.3 percent were dependent on or abused alcohol or illicit drugs. In 2001, there were 249,000 victims of rape in the United States. According to the National Victim's Center, 13.3 percent of college women have been forced to have sex in a dating situation. The National Eating Disorders Association reports that 5-10 million women and 1 million men struggle with eating disorders after puberty. SEC. 120A. MENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES ON CAMPUS. The purpose of this section is to increase access to mental and behavioral health services for college students on campus. Grants will be awarded to campus centers providing these services to develop best practices. Eligible entities include mental health service centers on the campus of higher education institutions. Eligible entities, such as college counseling centers, university psychological service centers, and psychology training clinics, can apply for grants under this section. Applications must include program objectives, outreach strategies, plans to reach students in need, program evaluation, and additional required information. Funds from the grant can be used for intervention programs addressing developmental issues, alcohol consumption, mental health services, self-management skills, chronic mental illness, and depressive disorders. The curr_chunk discusses various mental health services and programs that should be provided by eligible entities, including assessment and treatment of anxiety disorders, prevention programs for depression, anxiety, suicide, and domestic violence, education for eating disorders, treatment of sexual trauma, and psychological education for parents of college students. It also emphasizes the importance of hiring appropriately trained staff, strengthening psychology training programs, supporting evidence-based practices, and evaluating outcomes to improve mental and behavioral health services on campus. Each eligible entity receiving a grant must provide annual reports on fund usage, program objectives, and outcomes. They must also conduct additional evaluations as required by the Secretary, coordinating with related campus efforts for mental, health, and behavioral health needs of students. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2005 and necessary sums for the following 4 years for grants under this section.
